conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful question.

Here is the most accurate way to describe our decision rule within this process:

- We can only make decisions based on who actually contacts School_A in a given round.
- If we receive one or more [APPLY] messages in a round, we would extend our offer (if any) to the highest-priority applicant among those who applied to us that round.
- As long as we believe there is a meaningful chance that higher-priority students on our list (Student_B, Student_D, Student_A) may still apply to School_A in upcoming rounds, we may continue to hold the seat rather than commit it immediately to a lower-priority applicant.

So, even in a round where none of Student_B/Student_D/Student_A apply, it is not an automatic guarantee that we will extend an offer to the next applicant; it depends on whether we are still choosing to keep the seat available for potential higher-priority applicants in subsequent rounds.

I understand that this uncertainty is frustrating, and I appreciate your persistence. Given the above, I strongly encourage you to continue actively pursuing other schools where you have a clearer path to a match.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on our true priority list (behind Student_B, Student_D, Student_A). Our quota is 1 and currently unfilled. In this round, only Student_E contacted us, and they are using [TALK], not [APPLY], so no accept/reject decision is allowed. Given the market rules, we only observe who contacts us each round; we cannot verify whether higher-priority students are negotiating elsewhere. Strategy: continue to hold the seat for higher-priority students, but provide clear, process-based conditions under which we would consider E—namely, if in a given round we receive an [APPLY] from the highest-priority applicant among those who applied that round, and no higher-priority applicant applies, then we may extend an offer to the best available applicant. Avoid committing to a specific future round; encourage E to pursue other options while being transparent about low likelihood.

conversation.message:
Dear School_A Admissions Team,

Thank you for your continued communication. I remain very interested in School_A and, if offered the seat, I will accept immediately and commit.

Before I submit another formal [APPLY] this round, could you share whether School_A has any concrete trigger for ending the “hold for higher-priority applicants” policy? For example, is there a specific round cutoff, or a situation (e.g., no contact from Student_B/Student_D/Student_A for X consecutive rounds) after which you would be willing to fill the seat with the highest-priority applicant who applies that round (including me)?

If there is any realistic scenario where you would consider me soon, I’m ready to apply immediately.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_A remains unmatched and it is on my preference list (ranked 3rd). Repeated APPLY attempts have been rejected because School_A is holding the seat for higher-priority students. A TALK message is best to (1) signal credible willingness to commit immediately, (2) ask for any actionable condition under which they would stop holding the seat, and (3) avoid wasting another round on an automatic rejection if their policy is unchanged.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for the clear question.

At this time, we do not have a fixed, public “trigger” (e.g., a specific round number or X consecutive rounds without hearing from Student_B/Student_D/Student_A) that automatically ends our policy of holding the seat for higher-priority candidates. Our decision is reassessed round-by-round based on remaining time in the process and the likelihood that higher-priority students may still approach us.

What I can say concretely is:
- If you would like to be eligible for consideration in a given round, you should send an [APPLY] that round (we cannot make an offer off a [TALK] message).
- As we get closer to the end of the process, we will become more willing to fill the seat with the highest-priority applicant who applies to us in that round if we judge the chance of receiving a higher-priority application to be low.

I understand this is not the definitive cutoff you’re hoping for, but it is the most accurate description of how we are operating within this matching environment.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: School_A’s true priority is B > D > A > E > C. We have quota 1 and remain unmatched. In round 14, only Student_E contacted us, and they used [TALK], not [APPLY], so we cannot accept anyway. Strategically, we should continue holding for higher-priority students, but we also need to manage the risk of ending unmatched by round 30. Student_E is 4th on our list and has shown strong commitment, so they are a viable fallback if higher-priority students never approach. However, giving a hard cutoff too early weakens our chance to land B/D/A. Best response: be transparent that there is no fixed trigger, but indicate we will reassess later (e.g., late rounds) and that if they want to be considered in any given round they must submit [APPLY].
